Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cohomology, Deformations, and Invariants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Shepler and Witherspoon will develop a theory of deformations expanding that for graded Hecke algebras. They will study deformations of skew group algebras that combine groups of symmetries with algebras of functions. Particular deformations of these algebras arose independently in work by many prominent mathematicians in representation theory and noncommutative geometry, but many open questions remain. Shepler and Witherspoon will answer some of these questions using new tools created by blending methods from invariant theory, combinatorics, homological algebra, and representation theory. They also will solve some basic open problems about the structure and cohomology of Hopf algebras and prove several conjectures on modular reflection groups, invariant theory, and arrangements of hyperplanes.

Objects throughout the natural world reveal themselves through their symmetries, for example, crystals, molecules, DNA, and quantum systems. When we deform an object, we alter or even break the symmetry. Remarkably often, we discover new attributes of the object after studying its deformations. Shepler and Witherspoon's research program on graded Hecke algebras and related deformations addresses a variety of mathematical fields and grows from the exploding interest the mathematical community shows in graded Hecke algebras. Hecke algebras are pervasive throughout mathematics, appearing in algebra, geometry, number theory, combinatorics, topology, statistics, harmonic analysis, mathematical physics, special functions, quantum groups, knot theory, and conformal field theory. Shepler and Witherspoon are active in the mathematical community, mentoring students and postdocs, collaborating with international experts, and organizing conferences and workshops. Their research program supports these broader activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Witherspoon works on the mathematics of symmetry. One understands properties of objects in the natural world by studying their symmetry: for example, crystals, DNA, and the universe itself. Abstractly, symmetry is expressed as operations that leave an object fixed, such as rotations or reflections, and these operations combined formed what is called a group or an algebra. Many of Witherspoon's findings involve deformations, in which symmetry is broken, and one understands the original object and its relations through this break. Together with collaborators, during the grant period, Witherspoon developed more fully deformation theory and the related cohomology of algebras. She made progress on a conjecture about cohomology of some kinds of algebras, that would lead to better, more geometric, understanding of objects on which they act. She further developed this geometric point of view. She aided efforts to classify some kinds of algebras by using new techniques to find more examples. Witherspoon's research involves open questions in which many mathematicians are interested, and that are connected to many areas of mathematics. Witherspoon has disseminated her work by publishing many papers in research journals and by giving talks all over the world. 

Witherspoon's research program involves collaborations with many mathematicians and the training of postdocs and graduate students in the methods and topics of her program. She trained three PhD students during the grant period, two of whom graduated at the end, in Summer 2012, with one continuing. She mentored two postdocs at her institution during the grant period, writing papers with each. She co-organized meetings, including most recently an advanced studies institute in Mexico, for the training of young mathematicians, on topics related to her research program. She co-founded a seminar for first year graduate students at Texas A&M University that was designed to help new students make the transition to graduate studies and to introduce them to the areas of research represented at Texas A&M University.
